Award.AwardTitle: SCH: INT: Collaborative Research: FITTLE+: Theory and Models for Smartphone Ecological Momentary Intervention

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many health conditions are caused by unhealthy lifestyles and can be improved by behavior change. Traditional behavior-change methods (e.g., weight-loss clinics; personal trainers) have bottlenecks in providing expert personalized day-to-day support to large populations for long periods. There is a pressing need to extend the reach and intensity of existing successful health behavior change approaches in areas such as diet and fitness. Smartphone platforms provide an excellent opportunity for projecting maximally effective interventions for behavior change into everyday life at great economies of scale. Smartphones also provide an excellent opportunity for collecting rich, fine-grained data necessary for understanding and predicting behavior-change dynamics in people going about their everyday lives. The challenge posed by these opportunities for detailed measurement and intervention is that current theory is not equally fine-grained and predictive.

This interdisciplinary project investigates theory and methods to support fine-grained behavior-change modeling and intervention integrated via smartphone into the daily lives of individuals and groups. Fittle+ develops a new and transformative form of smartphone-delivered Ecological Momentary Intervention (EMI) for improving diet and physical activity. This approach will provide social support and autonomously planned and personalized coaching that builds on methods from mobile sensing, cognitive tutoring, and evidence-based social design. The foundation for this new approach will require new predictive computational theories of health behavior change. Current coarse-grained conceptual theories of individual health behavior change will be refined into fine-grained predictive computational models. These computational models will be capable of tracking moment-by-moment human context, activity, and social patterns based on mobile sensing and interaction data. Using these monitoring capabilities, Fittle+'s computational models will support assessment of, and predictions about, individual users and groups based on underlying motivational, cognitive, and social mechanisms. These predictive models will also be used to plan and optimize coaching actions including detailed diagnostics, individualized goals, and contextually and personally adapted interventions.

The collaborative team of researchers works with weight-loss interventionists at one of nation's largest health organization's facility in Hawaii. The team includes expertise in mobile sensing, artificial intelligence, computational cognition, social psychology, human computer interaction, computer tutoring, and measurement theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Final outcome report for the general public

Our research goals were to build and test evidence-based interventions for health behavior change. Our research teams have been collaborating with Kaiser Permanente to iteratively develop and test a novel smartphone-based Ecological Momentary Intervention (EMI) system called Fittle+ for exercise and weight loss, and with the American Cancer Society (ACS) to improve online health support groups.

Over several Fittle+ studies, we developed the concept of scaffolding interventions: Behavior-change techniques and associated mHealth interactions (e.g., SMS reminders; chatbot dialogs, etc.) that provide additional support to the acquisition and maintenance of healthy habits. Fittle+ systems offer users core challenges with daily goals. The scaffolding interventions provide additional support to increase the likelihood of achieving those goals.  Figure 1 summarizes the set of interventions explored in Fittle+. Guided mastery, teaming, and self-affirmation interventions are all targeted at strengthening behavior-change intentions, whereas implementation intentions are targeted at translating intentions into actual behavior. These interventions were selected based on prior research supporting their efficacy.

Healthy habits are learned gradually through the association of specific behaviors to triggering cues in the environment. We’ve built ACT-R computational models to simulate individual-level, day-by-day behavior-change success, which occurred in multi-week experiments on guided mastery and implementation intentions. The models integrate theories of goal setting, self-efficacy, reinforcement learning and the Attributional Theory of Performance. The models predict two phases of habit change: (1) deliberative goal-striving processes that guide seminal attempts at behavior and (2) habit acquisition and strengthening processes that establish stable new habits through repeated practice. Multiple ACT-R mechanisms simulate how Fittle+ influences new healthy habits. Instance-based learning mechanisms predict how adjustments in goal difficulty modulate self-efficacy and goal success. Memory learning mechanisms predict how the scheduling of reminders affects goal success and habit formation. Production compilation mechanisms model how new habits are acquired, and utility learning mechanisms adjust the utility of new habits.

As a complement to developing Fittle+, we built machine learning methods for human activity recognition (HAR), such as types of exercise. Our focus has been on handling problems typical of health domains, especially sparse training data and individual differences in how people carry out an activity. We developed machine learning methods to recognize new activities not encountered in the training data. To handle situations with little labeled data, we developed a hybrid feature-and attribute-based approach. Further, we developed adaptive techniques and techniques to handle situations in which datasets are highly imbalanced.  Because the distribution of data changes gradually when physical attributes (e.g., walking speed) change, we developed an algorithm that takes advantage of such changes during learning. We also found that combining individual-specific with impersonal machine learning models improves HAR accuracy.

While these machine learning methods rely on hand-crafted features, we have also used deep neural networks to automatically identify good feature representations. We have been the first to apply convolutional neural networks (CNN) to HAR.  Further, to overcome the challenges of few labeled samples and personal variability of behaviors, we adopted two semi-supervised CNN models, CNN-Encoder-Decoder and CNN-Ladder, to learn good representations when there is little labeled data.

In research parallel to Fittle+, we conducted empirical analyses to understand the exchange of social support in ACS’s online support groups and developed interventions to improve it. This research included the development of machine learning techniques to automatically measure in conversational precursors of social support, such as question-asking and self-disclosure, and different types of social support. We used these automated measures to understand key processes in support groups and as the basis of interventions. For support groups to be successful, they must retain members who contribute to them. Our research has examined how commitment to online support groups develops and the types of social interactions that predict willingness to help others. For example, we’ve shown that receiving communication generally predicts increased commitment, with its impact increasing with the time people spend in the group. However, receiving more informational or emotional support per message doesn’t improve commitment. One problem is that newcomers, who are most needy of communication, may drop out before they find interactions that are valuable for them. In contrast, those who stay do so because they have found content and interactions that match their needs.

To improve the success of online support groups, we have implemented, deployed and are testing recommendation interventions designed to connect members to content and to other members of interest to them, based on their browsing history on a site. We have started to conduct online tests to determine whether these enhancements are valuable, in the sense that they provide engaging content to members that they would not have seen otherwise, introduce them to other members who share their problems and lead them to participate more in the community.
